w:r.w:t: Exploring the Exotic Elements of Polluted White Dwarfs

I really liked this topic and the way you covered it. I was able to follow your explanation of the underlying science quite easily and I definitely learned some interesting things along the way. I was unaware that white dwarf atmospheric spectra could be used to help discover exotic exoplanets (only after they have been destroyed of course :p). The majority of my suggestions are based on personal preference for voice & sentence structure so feel free to ignore them. I hope they don’t come off as nit-picky. I also included a few small formatting comments, although it is
that the issues I noticed were just

by me opening the pdf through google docs. Some more important suggestions I have are regarding the ways you explained a few of the specific topics and they should be marked below. My biggest suggestion would be to mention the relevance of polluted white dwarfs to exoplanets much earlier. From the title/opening I would not have expected as much focus on exoplanet compositions as there is in the rest of your report.
I look forward to seeing your oral presentation!
Ninety-seven percent of all stars in
galaxy, including the Sun, will become a white dwarf at the end of their lifecycle (Fontaine
a main sequence star runs out of hydrogen, it burns through
heavier elements. This causes the star to expand by several AU in radius and cool to become an asymptotic giant branch star (Harrison
2018). Nearby rocky material and planets are engulfed by the star and quickly sink to the core.
At the end of the star’s life,
the outer layers of the star are ejected, forming a planetary nebula.
he core of the star becomes a white dwarf. The gravitational acceleration at the surface of a white dwarf can be 100 million times stronger than Earth’s
It was thought that this would leave
an atmosphere of pure hydrogen and helium
. However, in 1917, metal absorption lines were first observed in the spectra of a white dwarf (Harrison
The current estimate is that around
25% of all white dwarfs have atmospheres “polluted” by elements heavier than helium

olluted white dwarfs must have recently accreted rocky material.
The exact source of accreted material is not currently known. Theories
dynamical instabilities during the asymptotic giant branch phase
gravitational influence of a binary companion
planetary mean motion resonance to perturbed exomoons (Harrison 2018).
Entire asteroid belts or individual exoplanets and exomoons may have been accreted
. Each theory reflects a different stage of
and size of accreted object, but all require that the white dwarf atmosphere reflects the composition of exoplanetary material. When
object – wherever its origin – passes within the
Roche limit, it is shredded into a disk of gas and dust (Klein 2011). This accretion disk gradually deposits material into the white dwarf’s atmosphere.
atmosphere can have an effective temperature of over 20,000 K,

w:r.w:t: This means polluted white dwarfs are currently the most direct method of observing the composition of rocky exoplanetary material.
The origin and formation history of pollutant material can be constrained by element abundance ratios
Lithophiles are elements that preferentially form silicate minerals. Siderophile elements have a strong affinity for iron minerals, rather than silicates.

As shown in Figure 1, Earth's core, mantle, and crust have distinct ratios of lithophile and siderophile elements (Harrison 2018). Earth's iron core is enriched in siderophiles, while the mantle and crust are depleted because they are comparatively iron-poor (Harrison
2018). Earth's crust, which has abundant silicate minerals, is more enriched in lithophiles than the mantle (Harrison
2018). To a first order approximation, the same assumption can be made for the interiors of other exoplanets. This is used to determine the accreted object’s

. For example, a collision between differentiated objects could strip the crust and even mantle, leaving mostly core material. This would indicate the accreted object was one of multiple planets or planetesimals in the star system. Therefore, the composition of exoplanetary material and whether the object was differentiated can be
based on siderophile and lithophile ratios (Harrison

This suggests that polluted white dwarfs can reflect the composition of material that originated in a wide range of radial distances
. As a result, any theory of accretion mechanisms must be
able to explain the accretion of objects from a wide variety of orbital radii

w:r.w:t: A wide variety of elements h
been observed in polluted white dwarfs
exoplanet mineralogy. All major terrestrial elements have been detected in polluted white dwarfs (Klein
2011). Carbon, oxygen, nitrogen, sodium, magnesium, aluminum, silicon, calcium, titanium, chromium, iron, and nickel have all been detected in polluted white dwarfs (Harrison
Even rare elements such as vanadium, scandium, and uranium have been observed in helium white dwarfs, which have lower opacities than hydrogen white dwarfs (Klein
2021). The lower opacity allows metals of 10
times lower abundance than helium to be detected (Klein
Magnesium, iron, silicon, and oxygen are the most common elements in polluted white dwarfs, which parallels the composition of our solar system's rocky planets (Harrison
2018). However, the range of these element
our solar system. As shown in Figure 2,
span a larger range of ratios

w:r.w:delText: exceed the ranges of rocky exoplanet

w:r.w:t: compositions inferred from 4000 main sequence stars (Putirka & Xu
e are many possible explanations for such exotic ratios. A
polluted white dwarf with a high abundance of the volatiles carbon, nitrogen, and oxygen may have accreted a Kuiper Belt analogue (Harrison
2018). A high MgO and low SiO
polluted white dwarf likely accreted ultramafic mantle rocks such as peridotite and pyroxenite (Putirka & Xu
2021). A polluted white dwarf with high-potassium, high-magnesium, and low-silicon may
have accreted the hydrated upper mantle of a water world (Putirka & Xu

2021). The wide range of compositions indicates that polluted white dwarfs reflect new paths of planet formation and differentiation which do not have analogues in our own solar system and were not reflected in the compositions derived from main sequence star metallicity.
Comparison of bulk planet compositions of polluted white dwarfs, solar system planets, and FGKM stars in the Hypatia catalog (Putirka & Xu 2021).
Eleven of the twenty-three polluted white dwarfs considered in depth
had exotic compositions with no analogue in our own solar system
. Based on their elemental abundances, they
is surprising because olivine and orthopyroxene are two of the most common minerals on Earth. Over 90% of Earth's mantle is composed of olivine, orthopyroxene, and clinopyroxene
. Quartz and periclase are comparatively rare minerals in our solar system. This
could mean that the observations of these

which have no analogue in our solar system. Based on current theories of petrology, a quartz-rich mantle would create an exoplanet with a thick crust, while a periclase-rich mantle on a watery world would have a crust almost entirely composed of the mineral serpentine

w:r.w:delText: – which involves the outgassing of H

w:r.w:t: is one of two main fuel sources considered for the origin of life on Earth and on other worlds (the other being hydrothermal vents). Polluted white dwarfs
revealed exotic exoplanet compositions, which hold implications for astrobiology and planet formation

w:r.w:delText: Conclusion and Areas of Future Research

w:r.w:t: to determine the composition and mineralogy of exoplanetary material. A wide variety of exotic exoplanet compositions have been discovered, revealing that our theories of planet formation and the potential origin of life in the universe require modifications. However, there are large uncertainties in polluted white dwarfs' element abundance ratios,
up to 40% (Klein 2011). The main source of error is the depth and number of spectral lines which can be observed using infrared spectroscopy. This could be improved with additional observations.
